xxl.collections
Class DecoratorQueue

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.collections.DecoratorQueue
Direct Known Subclasses:
DistinctQueue, UnmodifiableQueue
public abstract class DecoratorQueue
extends Object
implements Queue

The class provides a decorator for a queue that follows the Decorator Design Pattern (for further details see Structural Patterns, Decorator in Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides). It provides a more flexible way to add functionality to a queue or one of its subclasses as by inheritance.

To provide this functionality the class contains a reference to the queue to be decorated. This reference is used to redirect method call to the original queue. This class is an abstract class although it provides no abstract methods. That's so because it does not make any sense to instanciate this class which redirects every method call to the corresponding method of the decorated queue without adding any functionality.

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new decorated queue that adds functionality to the insert method and leaves the
     // other methods untouched

     DecoratorQueue queue = new DecoratorQueue(new ListQueue()) {
         public void insert (Object object) {

             // every desired functionality can be added to this method

             System.out.println("Before the insertion of the specified object!");
             super.insert(object);
             System.out.println("After the insertion of the specified object!");
         }
     }

See Also:
Function, Iterator, NoSuchElementException

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new DecoratorQueue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). In contradiction to the contract in Queue it may only be invoked with an array (parameter list) (for further details see Function) of queues. The array (parameter list) will be used to initialize the decorated queue. This field is set to UnmodifiableQueue.FACTORY_METHOD.
See Also:
Function

queue

protected Queue queue
A reference to the queue to be decorated. This reference is used to perform method calls on the original queue.

Appends all of the elements in the specified iterator to the end of this queue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy. The behavior of this operation is unspecified if the specified iterator is modified while the operation is in progress.
Specified by:

Parameters:

            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Returns the next element in the queue without removing it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the queue (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. Because of thinkable interactions with other methods (e.g., the hasNext method of a Filter with an underlying iterator removes elements from the iterator) the correct working of a queue can only be guaranteed when remove is immediately called after calls to next or peek. The behavior of a queue is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the queue is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface Queue
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next method.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this queue.

replace

public Object replace(Object object)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Appends the specified element to the end of this queue and returns the next element in the queue. The end and the next element of the queue are given by its strategy.

replaceAll

public Iterator replaceAll(Iterator objects)
                    throws NoSuchElementException
Appends all of the elements in the specified iterator to the end of this queue and returns an iterator having the same length iterating over the replaced (next) elements of the queue. The end and the next element of the queue are given by its strategy.
Specified by:

Parameters:

Returns:

Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements in this queue. If this queue contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, returns Integer.MAX_VALUE.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek operation is supported by this queue. (In other words, returns true if peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Queue
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this queue.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
Note that the elements will only be removed from the queue but not from the underlying collection.
Specified by:
clear in interface Queue

close

public void close()
Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method takes the same effect as a single call.
Note: This method is very important for queues using external resources like files or JDBC resources.
Specified by:
close in interface Queue
